claim: All birds can fly. Penguins are birds. So penguins can fly

supporting.text: Penguins are flightless birds, as their wings are adapted for swimming rather than flying.

attacks.text: Penguins are flightless birds, as their wings are adapted for swimming rather than flying.
Some birds, like ostriches and emus, are also flightless, but they are still classified as birds.
The classification of birds is based on shared ancestry and traits like feathers and beaks, not just flight capability.
Penguins' wing structure is a specialized adaptation, not a disqualification from being birds.
Flightlessness in penguins evolved later; their ancestors were likely capable of flight.

supporting.text: Scientific classification confirms penguins as birds, but their physical structure prevents flight.

attacks.text: Scientific classification confirms penguins as birds, but their physical structure prevents flight.
Some bird species, like ostriches and emus, are also flightless but are still classified as birds.
The definition of birds is based on shared ancestry and characteristics like feathers, not just flight capability.
If flightlessness disqualifies penguins from being birds, then other flightless birds should also be excluded.
Biological classification prioritizes evolutionary relationships over individual traits like flight.

supporting.text: Observational evidence shows penguins cannot fly, despite being birds.

attacks.text: Observational evidence shows penguins cannot fly, despite being birds.
Penguins have evolved flippers for swimming, which are modified wings, making them flightless but still birds.
Flightlessness in penguins is an adaptation to their aquatic environment, not a disqualification from being birds.
Some bird species, like ostriches and emus, are also flightless but are universally recognized as birds.
The definition of birds is based on shared ancestry and features like feathers, not solely on the ability to fly.

supporting.text: Evolutionary biology explains penguins' loss of flight as an adaptation to aquatic life.

attacks.text: Evolutionary biology explains penguins' loss of flight as an adaptation to aquatic life.
Not all flightless birds lost flight due to aquatic adaptation; some evolved in terrestrial environments.
Penguins are a well-documented case where flightlessness directly correlates with aquatic specialization.
Flightlessness could theoretically re-evolve into flight under different environmental pressures.
No known bird species has re-evolved flight after becoming flightless, making this scenario speculative.
